title: WCAS PHIL 109-6-22 First-Year Seminar in Philosophy

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: We will discuss a range of classic philosophical texts, presenting different kinds of realism or idealism (in metaphysics, politics, ethics). We will consider questions such as: what does it mean to be an "idealist" or a "realist"? is mind or matter, both or neither the truly real? What would it mean to claim that the world does not (really) exist? Why would it be an insult - or not - to be called a political "idealist"? Or: if you are a criminal in virtual reality, are your crimes real, or not?

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
* To gain a sense of the wide range of meaning of central philosophical terms, in this case "ideal" and "real,"
* To understand some foundational philosophical debates
* To gain familiarity with some classic philosophical texts
* To be introduced to practices of philosophical interpretation and argument

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Course evaluation will be based on participation in class discussion; short writing assignments; two papers.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
George Berkeley, Three Dialogues Between Hylas and Philonous, Hackett 978-0915144617
Jennifer Haley, The Nether, Northwestern UP 9780810130630
Immanuel Kant, To Perpetual Peace, Hackett 978-0-87220-691-5
Thucydides, On Justice, Power, and Human Nature: Selections from the History of the Peloponnesian War, Hackett 978-0-87220-168-2

There will also be a course pack including selections from Raymond Geuss, Thomas More and others.
